types.name: AccessGrant
types.description:
An access grant is a combination of an Entity, a Role, and a Subject. It determines permissions for
said subject at the specific point in the hierarchy, and any child entities will inherit that role
as its accessControlList defines.

fields.name: entity
fields.description: The polymorphic entity to which access has been granted

fields.name: role
fields.description: The role the subject has been assigned

fields.name: subject
fields.description: The polymorphic subject that has been granted access

types.name: AccessGrantSubject

types.name: AnyScalarProperty
types.description:
`AnyScalarProperty` represents a collection of known *scalar* properties. In effect,
it includes every possible schema property type except for groups (`GroupProperty`).

This union is intended to iterate the properties within a group. To iterate over the
properties in a `SchemaInstance`, you should use `AnySchemaPropertyType` to ensure that
you are also seeing groups.

Any object contained within this union is guaranteed to implement `ScalarProperty`
as well as `SchemaProperty`.

types.name: AnySchemaProperty
types.description:
`AnySchemaProperty` represents the top level of a schema instance's properties. It can include any scalar property, as
well as any `GroupProperty` that the instance might have. To query only scalar properties, see `AnyScalarProperty`.

All properties contained in this union are guaranteed to implement `SchemaProperty`.

fields.name: array
fields.description:

comes in an array rather than representing a discrete piece of information.

See `AssetsProperty`, `ContributorsProperty`, `MultiselectProperty`, and `TagsProperty`
for examples.

fields.name: description
fields.description:
A human-readable description for the property. It should describe the purpose of the
property as well as some details about the types of values it looks for.

It can be rendered as help text, hints, etc.

fields.name: fullPath
fields.description:
The full path that represents the property on the schema instance. It is guaranteed
to be unique for the instance, and can be used to grab a property directly, as well as
facilitating schema validation and errors within the admin application's forms.

fields.name: function
fields.description: The purpose or intent of this property relative to its entity, parents, and others.

fields.name: isWide
fields.description:
Whether to render a field as "wide" (two columns) in the form.
This is intended to help structure forms logically, as well as
provide ample space for certain types of data input, particularly
full-text, markdown, and other such complex fields.

fields.name: kind
fields.description: Provided for introspection. This describes the underlying structure of the data type.

fields.name: label
fields.description: A human-readable label for the schema property.

fields.name: orderable
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. Whether this property can be used to order entities.
For certain data types, there's no sensible way to order properties.

fields.name: path
fields.description:
The "short" path for the property. For properties nested within a group, this can
be considered the name of the property without the group's prefix.

fields.name: required
fields.description:
Whether or not this property is required in order for the schema instance
to be considered valid.

Note: invalid data provided to a schema property will still invalidate
the instance as a whole—the required trait only determines whether a value
**must** be set.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. This represents the actual data type this property
uses.

Rendering in the frontend should rely primarily on the `AnySchemaProperty` and
`AnyScalarProperty` unions (in that order)`, rather than relying on this value,
since the actual implementations of these properties differ in the GraphQL types
associated with their values.

types.name: AttachmentStorage
types.description: This describes where a given file attachment is stored (if at all)

enumValues.name: STORE
enumValues.description: STORE refers to permanent storage. An asset here has been fully processed and is ready for access

enumValues.name: CACHE
enumValues.description:
CACHE refers to temporary storage. When a file is first uploaded to the system, it lives in cache and needs to be processed.
A user could potentially fetch something from an API while a file is still being processed in the background, and if so, none
of its derivatives will be present yet.

enumValues.name: DERIVATIVES
enumValues.description: Not yet used

enumValues.name: REMOTE
enumValues.description: Remote URL storage. Only used internally at present, but may sometimes appear during certain harvesting events.

in a tree structure.

In practice, this means a `Collection` or an `Item`, not a `Community`.

because in practice a schema should not have many associations.

fields.name: array
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. This describes whether or not the property's value
comes in an array rather than representing a discrete piece of information.

See `AssetsProperty`, `ContributorsProperty`, `MultiselectProperty`, and `TagsProperty`
for examples.

fields.name: description
fields.description:
A human-readable description for the property. It should describe the purpose of the
property as well as some details about the types of values it looks for.

It can be rendered as help text, hints, etc.

fields.name: fullPath
fields.description:
The full path that represents the property on the schema instance. It is guaranteed
to be unique for the instance, and can be used to grab a property directly, as well as
facilitating schema validation and errors within the admin application's forms.

fields.name: function
fields.description: The purpose or intent of this property relative to its entity, parents, and others.

fields.name: isWide
fields.description:
Whether to render a field as "wide" (two columns) in the form.
This is intended to help structure forms logically, as well as
provide ample space for certain types of data input, particularly
full-text, markdown, and other such complex fields.

fields.name: kind
fields.description: Provided for introspection. This describes the underlying structure of the data type.

fields.name: label
fields.description: A human-readable label for the schema property.

fields.name: orderable
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. Whether this property can be used to order entities.
For certain data types, there's no sensible way to order properties.

fields.name: path
fields.description:
The "short" path for the property. For properties nested within a group, this can
be considered the name of the property without the group's prefix.

fields.name: required
fields.description:
Whether or not this property is required in order for the schema instance
to be considered valid.

Note: invalid data provided to a schema property will still invalidate
the instance as a whole—the required trait only determines whether a value
**must** be set.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. This represents the actual data type this property
uses.

Rendering in the frontend should rely primarily on the `AnySchemaProperty` and
`AnyScalarProperty` unions (in that order)`, rather than relying on this value,
since the actual implementations of these properties differ in the GraphQL types
associated with their values.

fields.name: array
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. This describes whether or not the property's value
comes in an array rather than representing a discrete piece of information.

See `AssetsProperty`, `ContributorsProperty`, `MultiselectProperty`, and `TagsProperty`
for examples.

fields.name: description
fields.description:
A human-readable description for the property. It should describe the purpose of the
property as well as some details about the types of values it looks for.

It can be rendered as help text, hints, etc.

fields.name: fullPath
fields.description:
The full path that represents the property on the schema instance. It is guaranteed
to be unique for the instance, and can be used to grab a property directly, as well as
facilitating schema validation and errors within the admin application's forms.

fields.name: function
fields.description: The purpose or intent of this property relative to its entity, parents, and others.

fields.name: isWide
fields.description:
Whether to render a field as "wide" (two columns) in the form.
This is intended to help structure forms logically, as well as
provide ample space for certain types of data input, particularly
full-text, markdown, and other such complex fields.

fields.name: kind
fields.description: Provided for introspection. This describes the underlying structure of the data type.

fields.name: label
fields.description: A human-readable label for the schema property.

fields.name: orderable
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. Whether this property can be used to order entities.
For certain data types, there's no sensible way to order properties.

fields.name: path
fields.description:
The "short" path for the property. For properties nested within a group, this can
be considered the name of the property without the group's prefix.

fields.name: required
fields.description:
Whether or not this property is required in order for the schema instance
to be considered valid.

Note: invalid data provided to a schema property will still invalidate
the instance as a whole—the required trait only determines whether a value
**must** be set.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. This represents the actual data type this property
uses.

Rendering in the frontend should rely primarily on the `AnySchemaProperty` and
`AnyScalarProperty` unions (in that order)`, rather than relying on this value,
since the actual implementations of these properties differ in the GraphQL types
associated with their values.

fields.name: array

Provided for introspection. This describes whether or not the property's value
comes in an array rather than representing a discrete piece of information.

See `AssetsProperty`, `ContributorsProperty`, `MultiselectProperty`, and `TagsProperty`
for examples.

fields.name: description
fields.description:
A human-readable description for the property. It should describe the purpose of the
property as well as some details about the types of values it looks for.

It can be rendered as help text, hints, etc.

fields.name: fullPath
fields.description:
The full path that represents the property on the schema instance. It is guaranteed
to be unique for the instance, and can be used to grab a property directly, as well as
facilitating schema validation and errors within the admin application's forms.

fields.name: function
fields.description: The purpose or intent of this property relative to its entity, parents, and others.

fields.name: isWide
fields.description:
Whether to render a field as "wide" (two columns) in the form.
This is intended to help structure forms logically, as well as
provide ample space for certain types of data input, particularly
full-text, markdown, and other such complex fields.

fields.name: kind
fields.description: Provided for introspection. This describes the underlying structure of the data type.

fields.name: label
fields.description: A human-readable label for the schema property.

fields.name: orderable
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. Whether this property can be used to order entities.
For certain data types, there's no sensible way to order properties.

fields.name: path
fields.description:
The "short" path for the property. For properties nested within a group, this can
be considered the name of the property without the group's prefix.

fields.name: required
fields.description:
Whether or not this property is required in order for the schema instance
to be considered valid.

Note: invalid data provided to a schema property will still invalidate
the instance as a whole—the required trait only determines whether a value
**must** be set.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. This represents the actual data type this property
uses.

Rendering in the frontend should rely primarily on the `AnySchemaProperty` and
`AnyScalarProperty` unions (in that order)`, rather than relying on this value,
since the actual implementations of these properties differ in the GraphQL types
associated with their values.

only the shared kind, namespace, and identifier. The name is also most likely
shared, although it can change between schema versions, and the value on the
definition will default to whatever the most recent version uses.

types.name: SchemaPropertyFunction
types.description: Schema properties can serve various functions. This helps communicate the purpose of them, for building UIs, and general introspection.

enumValues.name: CONTENT
enumValues.description: This property acts as data inherently representative of the entity. Full text of an article, titling, and other such purposes.

enumValues.name: METADATA
enumValues.description:
This property is intended to offer further information about the content, but not necessarily the content itself.
Most metadata should be things that are filterable or searchable to help users find and learn more about related
content.

enumValues.name: PRESENTATION
enumValues.description:
This property is used for presenting information *about* the content, or how it should be formatted, but is less reflective
of the content itself. An option for changing a specific render style, an additional image to display, etc.

enumValues.name: SORTING
enumValues.description:
This property is only used when ordering this entity by ancestors. It should not generally be visible in the frontend, but
remain editable by admins to adjust ordering.

enumValues.name: UNSPECIFIED
enumValues.description:
This property's purpose remains unspecified and is likely the mark of a schema still in development. It should not generally
be in a finished schema, as it is important to help communicate the intent of a property for those building a UI.

types.name: SchemaPropertyKind
types.description:
The _kind_ of a data type for a schema property. Mostly informational
in the API, this value represents the underlying structure of the data type.

enumValues.name: GROUP
enumValues.description: A composite of other properties. See `GroupProperty`

enumValues.name: REFERENCE
enumValues.description:
A reference (or references) to other models in the system.

See `AssetProperty`, `ContributorsProperty` for examples

enumValues.name: COMPLEX
enumValues.description:
A complex data type that is composed of multiple subproperties
or requires other processing. Their values cannot be easily
mapped to GraphQL / JavaScript primitives.

See `VariableDateProperty`, `FullTextProperty` for examples.

enumValues.name: SIMPLE
enumValues.description:
The most common type of property, and what most values are likely to be. Strings,
integers, floats, booleans, and so on.

types.description: The data type for a schema property.

enumValues.name: BOOLEAN

enumValues.name: INTEGER
enumValues.description: A whole number. See `IntegerProperty`

enumValues.name: MARKDOWN

enumValues.description: Simple text values. See `StringProperty`

enumValues.name: TIMESTAMP

enumValues.name: URL

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DATE

enumValues.name: LEAVES_ONLY
enumValues.description: Fetch only nodes that are "leaves"; nodes that have a parent of the same type

types.name: UserProfileInput

fields.name: array
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. This describes whether or not the property's value
comes in an array rather than representing a discrete piece of information.

See `AssetsProperty`, `ContributorsProperty`, `MultiselectProperty`, and `TagsProperty`
for examples.

fields.name: description
fields.description:
A human-readable description for the property. It should describe the purpose of the
property as well as some details about the types of values it looks for.

It can be rendered as help text, hints, etc.

fields.name: fullPath
fields.description:
The full path that represents the property on the schema instance. It is guaranteed
to be unique for the instance, and can be used to grab a property directly, as well as
facilitating schema validation and errors within the admin application's forms.

fields.name: function
fields.description: The purpose or intent of this property relative to its entity, parents, and others.

fields.name: isWide
fields.description:
Whether to render a field as "wide" (two columns) in the form.
This is intended to help structure forms logically, as well as
provide ample space for certain types of data input, particularly
full-text, markdown, and other such complex fields.

fields.name: kind
fields.description: Provided for introspection. This describes the underlying structure of the data type.

fields.name: label
fields.description: A human-readable label for the schema property.

fields.name: orderable
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. Whether this property can be used to order entities.
For certain data types, there's no sensible way to order properties.

fields.name: path
fields.description:
The "short" path for the property. For properties nested within a group, this can
be considered the name of the property without the group's prefix.

fields.name: required
fields.description:
Whether or not this property is required in order for the schema instance
to be considered valid.

Note: invalid data provided to a schema property will still invalidate
the instance as a whole—the required trait only determines whether a value
**must** be set.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Provided for introspection. This represents the actual data type this property
uses.

Rendering in the frontend should rely primarily on the `AnySchemaProperty` and
`AnyScalarProperty` unions (in that order)`, rather than relying on this value,
since the actual implementations of these properties differ in the GraphQL types
associated with their values.

types.name: VariablePrecisionDate
types.description:
A wrapper around a date that allows us to describe a level of precision to apply to it,
which can be used in the frontend to affect its display.

fields.name: precision
fields.description: The level of precision: the frontend can make decisions about how to format the associated value based on this

fields.name: value
fields.description: The actual date, encoded in ISO8601 format (if available)

types.name: VariablePrecisionDateInput
types.description: A corresponding input type for VariablePrecisionDate.

inputFields.name: value
inputFields.description: The actual date, encoded in ISO8601 format (if available)

inputFields.name: precision
inputFields.description: The level of precision: the frontend can make decisions about how to format the associated value based on this

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name, description and optional `specifiedByUrl`, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields`, `interfaces`, and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FIELD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a variable definition.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.

directives.name: include
directives.description: Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true.

args.name: if
args.description: Included when true.

directives.name: skip
directives.description: Directs the executor to skip this field or fragment when the `if` argument is true.

args.name: if
args.description: Skipped when true.

directives.name: deprecated
directives.description: Marks an element of a GraphQL schema as no longer supported.

args.name: reason
args.description: Explains why this element was deprecated, usually also including a suggestion for how to access supported similar data. Formatted using the Markdown syntax, as specified by [CommonMark](https://commonmark.org/).

directives.name: specifiedBy
directives.description: Exposes a URL that specifies the behaviour of this scalar.

args.name: url
args.description: The URL that specifies the behaviour of this scalar.
